categories.name: Lore
categories.description: World terminology, history, and cultural terms

categories.name: Status Effects
categories.description: Conditions, buffs, debuffs, and temporary effects

terms.definition: A critical hit occurs when you roll the maximum value on your attack die, or when specific abilities trigger a critical. Critical hits deal double damage and ignore a portion of the target's armor. Some abilities and equipment can increase your critical hit chance or enhance critical damage.
terms.shortDefinition: Maximum damage roll dealing double damage and ignoring armor.
examples: Your strike finds a gap in the goblin's armor—Critical Hit! 24 damage.
The assassin's precise blow lands a critical, bypassing your shield.

terms.definition: The primary offensive action in combat. An attack roll is made against the target's defense value. If the roll meets or exceeds the defense, the attack hits and deals damage. Attack values are modified by your Might attribute, weapon quality, and active buffs.
terms.shortDefinition: Offensive combat action; roll against target's defense to deal damage.
examples: Your attack value is increased by +3 from your enchanted blade.

terms.definition: Your ability to avoid or reduce incoming attacks. Defense is calculated from your base value, armor, shield, and active stances. When an enemy attacks, they must roll equal to or higher than your defense value to hit. Higher defense means fewer hits land.
terms.shortDefinition: Value attackers must meet or exceed to hit you.

terms.definition: The amount of harm inflicted by an attack or ability. Damage is calculated from weapon base damage, attribute bonuses, and modifiers. Damage reduces the target's health points. Different damage types (physical, fire, ice, etc.) may have varying effectiveness against certain enemies.
terms.shortDefinition: Harm inflicted; reduces target's health based on weapon and modifiers.

terms.definition: The Norse magical tradition of runic chanting. Galdr practitioners invoke rune power through specific vocal patterns and inscribed symbols. Unlike sorcery which draws from internal reserves, Galdr channels ambient runic energy through disciplined incantation. Miscast Galdr can result in Blight corruption.
terms.shortDefinition: Norse runic magic invoked through chanting and inscribed runes.
examples: The skald's galdr echoes through the hall, runes glowing in response.
She traced the protective galdr, warding the camp against spirits.

terms.definition: Ancient symbols of power that form the basis of Galdr magic. Each rune represents a concept—fire, protection, strength—and can be inscribed, spoken, or gestured to invoke its power. Runes are organized into schools, and mastering a school unlocks more potent applications.
terms.shortDefinition: Magical symbol representing a concept; basis of Galdr magic.

terms.definition: A corruption that spreads through The Roots, tainting both technology and living beings. Runic Blight is believed to be a side effect of the catastrophe that ended the old world. Exposure to heavy Blight can cause mutations, madness, and transformation into Blighted creatures.
terms.shortDefinition: Corruption spreading through the land, tainting life and technology.

terms.definition: The catastrophic event that ended the old world and gave rise to the Runic Blight. Little is known about its true nature—whether it was a magical experiment gone wrong, divine punishment, or something else entirely. Understanding The Glitch is key to surviving in the blighted lands.
terms.shortDefinition: The catastrophe that ended the old world and created the Blight.

terms.definition: Mental strain accumulated through combat, trauma, environmental pressure, and difficult decisions. High stress can trigger psychological effects including panic, rage, or despair. Stress is reduced through rest, positive interactions, and certain abilities. Managing stress is crucial for long expeditions.
terms.shortDefinition: Mental strain; high levels trigger psychological effects.
examples: Your stress reaches critical levels—roll for affliction.

terms.definition: Physical power and raw strength. Might determines melee damage bonuses, carrying capacity, and success in feats of strength like breaking doors or grappling. Warriors and berserkers benefit most from high Might.
terms.shortDefinition: Physical strength; affects melee damage and carrying capacity.

terms.definition: Agility, precision, and quick reflexes. Finesse affects ranged accuracy, dodge chance, and delicate tasks like lockpicking. Rogues and archers benefit most from high Finesse.
terms.shortDefinition: Agility and precision; affects ranged accuracy and dodge.

terms.definition: Mental fortitude and magical aptitude. Will determines mana capacity, spell effectiveness, and resistance to fear and mind effects. Mages and skalds require high Will for their abilities.
terms.shortDefinition: Mental fortitude; affects mana capacity and spell power.

terms.definition: Mental acuity, perception, and learned knowledge. Wits affects perception checks, crafting quality, lore knowledge, and provides secondary Aether capacity. Scholars and crafters benefit most from high Wits.
terms.shortDefinition: Mental acuity; affects perception, crafting, and lore knowledge.

terms.definition: Physical toughness and endurance. Sturdiness determines maximum HP, damage resistance (soak), and resistance to physical ailments. All characters who expect to endure punishment benefit from high Sturdiness.
terms.shortDefinition: Physical toughness; affects max HP and damage resistance.

terms.definition: An attribute allocation mode for character creation that uses archetype-recommended builds. In Simple mode, players select an archetype and attributes are automatically set to predefined values. Manual adjustment is disabled, providing the fastest path through character creation for new players.
terms.shortDefinition: Guided attribute allocation using archetype-recommended builds.

terms.definition: An attribute allocation mode for character creation that enables full point-buy customization. In Advanced mode, all attributes start at 1 and the player distributes points manually. Cost scaling applies at higher values (9-10 cost 2 points each). Players have complete control over their attribute distribution.
terms.shortDefinition: Full point-buy attribute customization for experienced players.

terms.definition: A damage-over-time status effect caused by fire. Burning targets take fire damage at the start of each turn and may spread the effect to adjacent allies. Burning can be removed by water, rolling on the ground (takes an action), or specific abilities.
terms.shortDefinition: Fire DoT; deals damage each turn, may spread to allies.
examples: The dragon's breath leaves you Burning (3 damage/turn for 3 turns).
Roll to extinguish or take 5 fire damage.

terms.definition: A disabling status effect caused by extreme cold. Frozen targets cannot act and have reduced defense. The effect ends after a set duration or when the target takes fire damage. Frozen targets take double damage from physical attacks but are immune to additional cold effects.
terms.shortDefinition: Disabled by cold; cannot act, reduced defense, weak to physical.

terms.definition: The quality tier of equipment and items. Rarity affects base statistics, available enchantment slots, and resale value. From lowest to highest: Common (white), Uncommon (green), Rare (blue), Epic (purple), Legendary (orange), Artifact (red).
terms.shortDefinition: Item quality tier from Common to Artifact; affects stats and slots.
examples: You found a Rare sword with two enchantment slots.
Legendary items can only be obtained from bosses.

terms.definition: Your character's physical vitality. When health reaches zero, you are incapacitated or dead depending on game settings. Health is restored through rest, potions, and healing abilities. Maximum health is determined by Constitution and level.
terms.shortDefinition: Physical vitality; at zero you are incapacitated or dead.

terms.definition: The ability to completely avoid incoming attacks through agility and reflexes. Unlike defense which reduces hit chance, successful evasion negates an attack entirely. Evasion is primarily derived from Finesse and light armor bonuses.
terms.shortDefinition: Chance to completely dodge an attack; derived from Finesse.

terms.definition: Taking time to recover health, reduce stress, and prepare for challenges ahead. Rest can be short (brief pause during exploration) or long (camping overnight). Long rests fully restore resources but may trigger random encounters or advance time.
terms.shortDefinition: Recovery action; restores health, reduces stress, may trigger events.

terms.definition: Mental resilience and determination. High resolve reduces stress gain and provides bonuses against fear and morale effects. Resolve can also be spent on certain powerful abilities that require unwavering focus.
terms.shortDefinition: Mental resilience; reduces stress gain and resists fear.

terms.definition: The Advanced mode system for manually allocating attribute points during character creation. Each attribute starts at 1, and players spend points from a shared pool to increase individual attributes. The cost structure uses tiered pricing: values 2-8 cost 1 point each (standard tier), while values 9-10 cost 2 points each (premium tier). Most archetypes receive 15 starting points; Adept receives 14.
terms.shortDefinition: Manual attribute allocation using a point pool with tiered costs.

terms.definition: Attribute values 9 and 10 in the point-buy system that cost 2 points per increment instead of the standard 1 point. Investing in premium tier values represents exceptional ability but significantly limits the points available for other attributes. The cumulative cost to reach value 10 from base is 11 points.
terms.shortDefinition: Attribute values 9-10 costing 2 points each instead of 1.

terms.definition: Secondary character statistics calculated from core attributes, archetype bonuses, and lineage bonuses. Derived stats include Max HP, Max Stamina, Max Aether Pool, Initiative, Soak, Movement Speed, and Carrying Capacity. Each stat is computed using a configurable formula that combines a base value with attribute scaling multipliers and optional bonuses.
terms.shortDefinition: Calculated secondary stats from attributes and bonuses.

terms.definition: Service that loads and caches attribute descriptions, archetype-recommended builds, and point-buy configuration from config/attributes.json. The Attribute Provider is the centralized access point for all attribute-related data during character creation, supporting both Simple mode (recommended builds) and Advanced mode (point-buy) allocation.
terms.shortDefinition: Centralized service for attribute data access during character creation.

terms.definition: Maximum hit points determining how much damage a character can absorb before falling. Calculated as (STURDINESS × 10) + 50 + archetype bonus + lineage bonus. Warrior archetype has the highest HP bonus (+49), while Clan-Born lineage adds +5.
terms.shortDefinition: Maximum hit points scaled by Sturdiness.

terms.definition: Maximum stamina pool for physical actions. Calculated as (FINESSE × 5) + (MIGHT × 5) + 20 + archetype bonus. Used by Warrior, Skirmisher, and Adept archetypes to power physical abilities. Warrior and Skirmisher archetypes receive a +5 bonus.
terms.shortDefinition: Maximum stamina scaled by Finesse and Might.

terms.definition: Maximum magical energy capacity for Aetheric abilities. Calculated as (WILL × 10) + (WITS × 5) + archetype bonus + lineage bonus, with an optional lineage multiplier. The Mystic archetype gains +20 bonus. Rune-Marked lineage adds +5 flat bonus then applies a ×1.10 multiplier from the Aether-Tainted trait.
terms.shortDefinition: Maximum magical energy scaled by Will and Wits.

terms.definition: Combat turn order bonus determining when a character acts in combat rounds. Calculated as FINESSE + (WITS ÷ 2) using integer division. Higher initiative means acting earlier, providing a tactical advantage for positioning and first strikes.
terms.shortDefinition: Combat turn order bonus from Finesse and Wits.

terms.definition: Passive damage reduction applied to incoming physical damage. Calculated as (STURDINESS ÷ 2) + lineage bonus. Iron-Blooded lineage gains +2 Soak from the Hazard Acclimation trait, making them notably more resilient to physical attacks.
terms.shortDefinition: Flat damage reduction from Sturdiness.

terms.definition: Base number of tiles a character can move per combat turn. Base value is 5 for all characters. Vargr-Kin lineage gains +1 from the Primal Clarity trait, reflecting their primal connection and physical agility.
terms.shortDefinition: Tiles moved per turn, base 5.

terms.definition: Service that manages attribute point allocation during character creation. Supports both Simple mode (archetype-recommended builds with no manual adjustment) and Advanced mode (full point-buy customization). Handles state creation, attribute modification with cost validation, mode switching, allocation validation, and reset. All state transitions are immutable, returning new state objects.
terms.shortDefinition: Service managing attribute point allocation during character creation.

terms.definition: Value object encapsulating the outcome of an attribute modification attempt during character creation. On success, contains the updated allocation state with modified attribute value and recalculated point totals. On failure, contains an error message describing why the modification was rejected (e.g., insufficient points, out-of-range value, Simple mode restriction).
terms.shortDefinition: Outcome of an attribute modification attempt with state or error.

terms.definition: Value object representing the outcome of an attribute allocation validation check, supporting multiple error messages for comprehensive feedback. Checks all attribute values are within range (1-10), points are not overspent, and Simple mode has an archetype selected. All constraints are checked simultaneously, reporting all violations at once.
terms.shortDefinition: Multi-error validation result for attribute allocation state.

terms.definition: Application service that computes derived statistics (Max HP, Max Stamina, Max Aether Pool, Initiative, Soak, Movement Speed, Carrying Capacity) from core attributes, archetype bonuses, and lineage bonuses using configurable formulas. Supports calculating all stats at once, single stat lookup by name, and live preview from an attribute allocation state during character creation. Uses formula-driven architecture where each stat has a base value, attribute scaling multipliers, optional archetype bonuses, optional lineage bonuses, and optional lineage multipliers applied in order.
terms.shortDefinition: Service that computes derived stats from attributes using configurable formulas.

terms.definition: A permanent character creation choice that defines the character's fundamental combat role, primary resource pool (Stamina or Aether Pool), starting abilities, and available specializations. The four archetypes are Warrior (Tank / Melee DPS), Skirmisher (Mobile DPS), Mystic (Caster / Control), and Adept (Support / Utility). Archetype cannot be changed after character creation.
terms.shortDefinition: Permanent combat role choice determining resource pool and abilities.

terms.definition: The Tank / Melee DPS archetype. Warriors are frontline fighters who absorb punishment and deal devastating melee damage. They use Stamina as their primary resource and have the highest HP bonus (+49) of any archetype. Warriors have 6 available specializations: Berserkr, Iron-Bane, Skjaldmaer, Skar-Horde, Atgeir-Wielder, and Gorge-Maw.
terms.shortDefinition: Tank / Melee DPS archetype with highest HP and Stamina resource.

terms.definition: The Mobile DPS archetype. Skirmishers excel at mobility and precision strikes, weaving in and out of combat. They use Stamina as their primary resource and have +1 Movement bonus. Skirmishers have 4 available specializations: Veiðimaðr, Myrk-gengr, Strandhögg, and Hlekkr-master.
terms.shortDefinition: Mobile DPS archetype with enhanced movement and Stamina resource.

terms.definition: The Caster / Control archetype. Mystics channel the corrupted Aether to unleash devastating magical attacks from range. They are the only archetype using Aether Pool as their primary resource and have +20 AP bonus. Mystics have 2 available specializations: Seiðkona and Echo-Caller.
terms.shortDefinition: Caster / Control archetype using Aether Pool for ranged magical attacks.

terms.definition: The Support / Utility archetype. Adepts master mundane arts and make the most of limited resources. They use Stamina as their primary resource and have a unique +20% consumable effectiveness bonus. Adepts receive 14 starting attribute points instead of the standard 15. They have 5 available specializations: Bone-Setter, Jötun-Reader, Skald, Scrap-Tinker, and Einbúi.
terms.shortDefinition: Support / Utility archetype with +20% consumable effectiveness.

terms.definition: The primary resource pool type used by an archetype for powering abilities. There are two resource types: Stamina (physical resource used by Warrior, Skirmisher, and Adept) and Aether Pool (magical resource used exclusively by Mystic). The resource type determines regeneration rates, ability costs, and synergies with lineage traits.
terms.shortDefinition: Primary ability resource pool: Stamina (physical) or Aether Pool (magical).

terms.definition: The set of resource pool bonuses provided by each archetype during character creation. Each archetype has a distinct bonus profile affecting Max HP, Max Stamina, Max Aether Pool, and Movement Speed. Warrior: +49 HP, +5 Stamina. Skirmisher: +30 HP, +5 Stamina, +1 Movement. Mystic: +20 HP, +20 Aether Pool. Adept: +30 HP, +20% Consumable Effectiveness.
terms.shortDefinition: Resource pool bonuses (HP, Stamina, AP, Movement) granted by archetype.

terms.definition: A unique archetype effect that cannot be expressed as a simple numeric bonus to resource pools. Currently only the Adept archetype has a special bonus: +20% Consumable Effectiveness, which multiplies all consumable item effects by 1.20. Special bonuses are defined by a bonus type identifier, a numeric value, and a description.
terms.shortDefinition: Unique archetype effect beyond standard resource bonuses (e.g., Adept's +20% consumables).

terms.definition: Classification of abilities by activation behavior. There are three ability types: Active (player-activated abilities that cost resources and have cooldowns), Passive (always-on abilities that provide constant benefits with no activation), and Stance (toggleable modes that modify character behavior while active). Each archetype's starting abilities include a mix of these types.
terms.shortDefinition: Ability classification: Active (activated), Passive (always-on), Stance (toggleable).

terms.definition: A starting ability granted by an archetype during character creation. Each archetype provides exactly 3 starting abilities that define the character's initial combat capabilities. Abilities are identified by a kebab-case ID (e.g., 'power-strike') and classified by AbilityType (Active, Passive, or Stance). Warrior receives Power Strike, Defensive Stance, and Iron Will. Skirmisher receives Quick Strike, Evasive Maneuvers, and Opportunist. Mystic receives Aether Bolt, Aether Shield, and Aether Sense. Adept receives Precise Strike, Assess Weakness, and Resourceful.
terms.shortDefinition: Starting ability (3 per archetype) granted during character creation.

terms.definition: A mapping between an archetype and its available specializations during character creation. Each archetype has access to a curated subset of specializations, with one recommended as the player's first choice. Specialization counts vary by archetype: Warrior (6: Guardian, Berserker, Weapon Master, Vanguard, Juggernaut, Battle Commander), Adept (5: Alchemist, Artificer, Tactician, Herbalist, Chronicler), Skirmisher (4: Shadow Dancer, Duelist, Ranger, Acrobat), and Mystic (2: Elementalist, Void Weaver). The first specialization is free at character creation.
terms.shortDefinition: Mapping of archetypes to their available specializations and recommended first choice.

terms.definition: The infrastructure service that loads archetype definitions from archetypes.json configuration and provides cached access to all archetype-related data: definitions (v0.17.3a), resource bonuses (v0.17.3b), starting abilities (v0.17.3c), specialization mappings (v0.17.3d), and recommended builds (v0.17.3e). Implements IArchetypeProvider with thread-safe double-checked locking initialization.
terms.shortDefinition: Service providing cached access to archetype definitions from JSON config.

terms.definition: A pre-configured attribute allocation optimized for a specific archetype's combat role, used in Simple mode character creation. Each build defines values for the five core attributes (Might, Finesse, Wits, Will, Sturdiness) and may optionally specify an optimal lineage for further synergy. Standard builds: Warrior (M4 F3 Wi2 Wl2 S4, 15 pts), Skirmisher (M3 F4 Wi3 Wl2 S3, 15 pts), Mystic (M2 F3 Wi4 Wl4 S2, 15 pts), Adept (M3 F3 Wi3 Wl2 S3, 14 pts).
terms.shortDefinition: Pre-configured attribute allocation for quick-start character creation.

terms.definition: Application layer service that orchestrates applying an archetype to a character during creation Step 4. Validates preconditions (null character, existing archetype, valid enum, definition exists), retrieves archetype data from IArchetypeProvider, applies resource bonuses (HP, Aether Pool, Movement) and starting abilities to the Player entity, and returns an ArchetypeApplicationResult capturing all changes. Archetype selection is permanent and cannot be changed after character creation.
terms.shortDefinition: Service applying archetype bonuses, abilities, and specializations during creation.

terms.definition: Value object capturing the comprehensive result of applying an archetype to a character during creation Step 4. On success, contains the applied archetype, resource bonuses applied (ArchetypeResourceBonuses), abilities granted (list of ArchetypeAbilityGrant), and available specializations (ArchetypeSpecializationMapping). On failure, contains a human-readable failure reason. Provides display methods: GetSummary(), GetGrantedAbilitiesList(), and GetSpecializationsList().
terms.shortDefinition: Result of applying an archetype containing granted bonuses, abilities, and specializations.

terms.definition: Lightweight value object representing the outcome of validating whether an archetype can be applied to a character. Contains IsValid (bool) and Issues (list of validation failure descriptions). Factory methods: Valid() for passing validation and Invalid(issues) for failing validation with one or more reasons. Used by IArchetypeApplicationService.CanApplyArchetype() to pre-check preconditions before application.
terms.shortDefinition: Validation check result for archetype application preconditions.

terms.definition: Classifies specializations by their relationship with reality and the Aether. Coherent paths work within stable reality with no Corruption risk from abilities, while Heretical paths interface with corrupted Aether and some abilities may trigger Corruption gain. Path type is permanent and determined by the specialization itself. Of 17 total specializations, 5 are Heretical (Berserkr, Gorge-Maw, Myrk-gengr, Seiðkona, Echo-Caller) and 12 are Coherent.
terms.shortDefinition: Coherent or Heretical classification determining Corruption risk.

terms.definition: Unique identifier for each of the 17 specializations across 4 archetypes: Warrior (6: Berserkr, Iron-Bane, Skjaldmaer, Skar-Horde, Atgeir-Wielder, Gorge-Maw), Skirmisher (4: Veiðimaðr, Myrk-gengr, Strandhögg, Hlekkr-master), Mystic (2: Seiðkona, Echo-Caller), and Adept (5: Bone-Setter, Jötun-Reader, Skald, Scrap-Tinker, Einbúi). Each specialization provides a tactical identity through unique ability trees, special resources, and path type classification.
terms.shortDefinition: Enum identifying all 17 specializations across 4 archetypes.

terms.definition: Extension methods for SpecializationId and SpecializationPathType enums providing path type lookups (GetPathType), parent archetype mappings (GetParentArchetype), Heretical checks (IsHeretical), display names with Old Norse diacritics (GetDisplayName), Corruption risk descriptions (GetCorruptionRisk), Corruption risk evaluation (RisksCorruption), creation warnings (GetCreationWarning), and path type descriptions (GetDescription). All methods use O(1) switch expressions.
terms.shortDefinition: Extension methods for specialization path type lookups and display names.

terms.definition: Value object defining a unique gameplay resource tied to a specific specialization. Unlike standard resources (Health, Stamina, Aether Pool), special resources provide unique mechanics for certain specializations. Each definition includes a resource ID, display name, min/max value range, starting value, passive regeneration and decay rates, and a flavor description. Five specializations have special resources: Berserkr (Rage, 0-100), Skjaldmaer (Block Charges, 0-3), Iron-Bane (Righteous Fervor, 0-50), Seiðkona (Aether Resonance, 0-10), and Echo-Caller (Echoes, 0-5). The remaining 12 specializations use SpecialResourceDefinition.None.
terms.shortDefinition: Value object defining a unique specialization resource with range, regen, and decay.

terms.definition: Entity defining a specialization's display metadata, path type classification, parent archetype, unlock cost, and optional special resource. Each of the 17 specializations has exactly one definition loaded from specializations.json configuration. Definitions include a display name (with Old Norse diacritics), tagline, lore description, second-person selection text for character creation, parent archetype linkage, Coherent/Heretical path type, Progression Point unlock cost (0 for first specialization, 3 for additional), and an optional SpecialResourceDefinition. Validated during creation to ensure path type and parent archetype match the SpecializationId enum's inherent values.
terms.shortDefinition: Entity defining specialization display metadata, path type, and special resource.

terms.definition: Value object representing an individual ability within a specialization tier. Each ability has mechanical properties including a unique kebab-case ID, display name, description, active/passive classification, resource cost and type, cooldown in turns, and Corruption risk for Heretical paths. Passive abilities are always in effect once the tier is unlocked and cannot have cooldowns. Active abilities require manual activation and may have resource costs and cooldowns. Ability IDs are normalized to lowercase for consistent lookups. Each specialization has 7-12 abilities distributed across three tiers.
terms.shortDefinition: Value object representing an individual ability with cost, cooldown, and Corruption risk properties.

terms.definition: Value object representing a tier of abilities within a specialization. Each specialization has three tiers with escalating Progression Point costs and rank requirements. Tier 1 (0 PP, Rank 1) provides core abilities free on selection. Tier 2 (2 PP, Rank 2) requires Tier 1 and provides advanced abilities. Tier 3 (3 PP, Rank 3) requires Tier 2 and provides pinnacle abilities. Each tier contains 2-4 abilities (mix of active and passive). The CanUnlock method validates rank requirements, previous tier prerequisites, and available PP before allowing unlock.
terms.shortDefinition: Value object representing a tier of abilities with unlock cost, rank requirements, and contained abilities.

terms.definition: Service that loads, caches, and provides access to all 17 specialization definitions from specializations.json configuration. Implements ISpecializationProvider with O(1) dictionary lookups by specialization ID, archetype, and path type. Loaded once at startup and registered as a singleton. Provides filtered access to Heretical (5) and Coherent (12) specializations, specializations with special resources (5), and cross-specialization ability lookups.
terms.shortDefinition: Service for loading and caching specialization definitions from JSON config with O(1) lookups.

terms.definition: Data Transfer Object classes for deserializing the specializations.json configuration file. Includes SpecializationsConfigDto (root), SpecializationPathTypeEntryDto (path type array entries), SpecializationDefinitionDto (definition entries with display metadata), SpecialResourceDto (optional unique combat resource), AbilityTierDto (tier progression structure), and SpecializationAbilityDto (individual ability properties). All properties auto-initialize for safe deserialization with System.Text.Json using case-insensitive property matching.
terms.shortDefinition: DTO classes for deserializing specializations.json configuration file.

terms.definition: Application service that orchestrates applying specializations to characters during character creation Step 5 and managing ability tier unlocks during progression. Validates archetype compatibility, deducts Progression Points, grants Tier 1 abilities, initializes special resources, and tracks Heretical path Corruption warnings. Depends on ISpecializationProvider for specialization definitions.
terms.shortDefinition: Service for applying specializations and managing tier unlocks.

terms.definition: Sealed value object capturing the outcome of applying a specialization to a character, including the applied definition, granted Tier 1 abilities, special resource initialization status, Heretical path warnings, PP cost, and any failure reasons. Created via factory methods Succeeded, Failed, AlreadyHasSpecialization, CharacterRequired, and ArchetypeMismatch.
terms.shortDefinition: Result value object for specialization application outcomes.

terms.definition: Sealed value object capturing the outcome of unlocking a specialization ability tier, including the unlocked tier definition, granted abilities, PP cost, and any failure reasons. Tier 1 is free with specialization selection, Tier 2 costs 2 PP and requires Rank 2, Tier 3 costs 3 PP and requires Rank 3. Created via factory methods Succeeded and Failed.
terms.shortDefinition: Result value object for tier unlock outcomes.

terms.definition: Enum defining the six sequential steps in the character creation wizard: Lineage (Step 1, blood heritage), Background (Step 2, pre-Silence profession), Attributes (Step 3, point allocation), Archetype (Step 4, PERMANENT combat role), Specialization (Step 5, tactical identity), and Summary (Step 6, review and name entry). Values are explicitly assigned 0-5 for arithmetic navigation via GetNextStep and GetPreviousStep extension methods.
terms.shortDefinition: Enum defining the six steps in the character creation wizard.

terms.definition: Transient entity maintaining all player selections throughout the character creation process. Tracks the current step, lineage, background, attributes, archetype, specialization, and character name. Supports forward/backward navigation via TryAdvance and TryGoBack methods while preserving choices. The IsComplete property returns true only when all required selections are present and there are no validation errors. Not persisted to the database — only the final character entity is saved upon confirmation.
terms.shortDefinition: Entity tracking all selections during character creation.

terms.definition: JSON configuration file (creation-workflow.json) defining the character creation workflow parameters: step order with display names and descriptions, navigation rules (canGoBack, isPermanent), permanent choice warnings, name validation rules (2-20 characters, ASCII letters/spaces/hyphens, profanity filter), and character initialization defaults (starting Legend, PP, Milestone, Stress values and resource maximization). Validated against creation-workflow.schema.json (Draft-07).
terms.shortDefinition: JSON config defining creation workflow steps and validation rules.

terms.definition: Immutable readonly record struct (CharacterCreationViewModel) containing all presentation data for the character creation wizard. Includes step information (title, description, step number), navigation state (canGoBack, canGoForward, isPermanentChoice), current selection display names (lineage, background, archetype, specialization, character name), preview data (DerivedStatsPreview, AbilitiesPreview, EquipmentPreview), and validation status. Rebuilt by the ViewModelBuilder on every state change.
terms.shortDefinition: Read-only presentation data for the character creation wizard.

terms.definition: Read-only value object (DerivedStatsPreview) providing a simplified view of derived statistics during character creation. Shows the three primary resource pools (MaxHp, MaxStamina, MaxAp) with source breakdown by lineage and archetype bonuses. Updated in real-time during attribute allocation (Step 3). MaxAp maps to MaxAetherPool in the domain model.
terms.shortDefinition: Preview of HP, Stamina, and AP with bonus source breakdown.

terms.definition: Read-only value object (AbilitiesPreview) listing ability names that will be granted during character creation. Separates abilities by source: archetype starting abilities (3 abilities from Step 4) and specialization Tier 1 abilities (2-4 abilities from Step 5). Populated in two stages as archetype and specialization are selected.
terms.shortDefinition: Preview of archetype and specialization abilities.

terms.definition: Read-only value object (EquipmentPreview) listing starting equipment items based on background selection during character creation. Each item (EquipmentPreviewItem) has a display name (kebab-case ItemId converted to title case), quantity, and derived item type (equipment slot name for equipped items, 'Consumable' for multi-quantity non-equipped items, 'Item' for single non-equipped items).
terms.shortDefinition: Preview of starting equipment from background selection.

terms.definition: Application service (ViewModelBuilder implementing IViewModelBuilder) that transforms CharacterCreationState into CharacterCreationViewModel. Coordinates with five providers: ILineageProvider (display names, HP/AP bonuses), IBackgroundProvider (display names, equipment grants), IArchetypeProvider (display names, resource bonuses, starting abilities), ISpecializationProvider (display names, Tier 1 abilities), and IDerivedStatCalculator (derived stat calculation). Constructs a fresh ViewModel on every call with no caching.
terms.shortDefinition: Service that builds creation ViewModel from state and providers.

terms.definition: Application service (NameValidator implementing INameValidator) that validates character names against configurable rules during Step 6 (Summary) of the character creation wizard. Checks names against six sequential rules: required, minimum length (2), maximum length (20), boundary (starts/ends with ASCII letter), allowed characters (ASCII letters, spaces, hyphens only), and profanity filter (case-insensitive substring and word matching). Provides Sanitize() for diacritics normalization (e.g., ö → o) and IsValid() for quick boolean checks. Configuration loaded from the nameValidation section of creation-workflow.json. Operates independently of the domain-level PlayerNameValidator which has different constraints.
terms.shortDefinition: Application service for configurable character name validation with profanity filtering and sanitization.

terms.definition: Immutable value object (readonly record struct) returned by INameValidator.Validate() containing three properties: IsValid (whether the name passed all rules), ErrorMessage (user-friendly failure description, null when valid), and SuggestedName (automatically corrected version from Sanitize(), null when no correction possible or name is valid). Created via factory methods Valid() and Invalid(errorMessage, suggestedName). Error messages are specific to the failing rule: 'Name is required.', 'Name must be at least 2 characters.', 'Name must be at most 20 characters.', 'Name must start and end with a letter.', 'Name can only contain letters, spaces, and hyphens.', 'Please choose a different name.' (profanity).
terms.shortDefinition: Value object containing name validation status, error message, and optional suggested correction.

terms.definition: Immutable value object (readonly record struct) containing configurable parameters for character name validation. Properties: MinLength (int, default 2), MaxLength (int, default 20), AllowedPattern (regex string for character validation), ProfanityFilter (IReadOnlyList<string> of blocked words). Loaded from the nameValidation section of creation-workflow.json configuration file. The Default static property provides standard values for unit testing and fallback scenarios. Consumed by the NameValidator application service constructor.
terms.shortDefinition: Configuration value object for name validation rules loaded from creation-workflow.json.

terms.definition: Immutable value object representing the outcome of a step selection or navigation action in the character creation workflow. Contains success status, current and next step information, validation errors (if any), and the updated ViewModel for TUI rendering. Returned by all ICharacterCreationController step methods.
terms.shortDefinition: Result of a creation workflow step action

terms.definition: Immutable value object representing the final outcome of character creation. Contains either the successfully created Player entity or validation errors explaining why creation failed (invalid name, incomplete state, factory unavailable). Returned by ICharacterCreationController.ConfirmCharacterAsync().
terms.shortDefinition: Final result of character creation with Player or errors

terms.definition: Application service orchestrating the 6-step character creation workflow. Manages state transitions, validates selections against domain providers (lineage, background, archetype, specialization), coordinates with the ViewModel builder for TUI rendering, and delegates final character creation to the character factory. Provides forward/backward navigation and session lifecycle management.
terms.shortDefinition: Orchestrator for the character creation workflow

terms.definition: Interface defining the contract for the character creation workflow controller. Specifies step selection methods (lineage, background, attributes, archetype, specialization, confirm), navigation controls (GoBack, Cancel), state retrieval (GetCurrentState), and session status (IsSessionActive). Implemented by CharacterCreationController.
terms.shortDefinition: Interface for the creation workflow controller

terms.definition: Application service (CharacterFactory implementing ICharacterFactory) that transforms a completed CharacterCreationState into a fully initialized Player entity via a 13-step initialization sequence. Steps include: state validation, Player construction with base attributes, lineage attribute modifiers (including Clan-Born flexible +1), lineage passive bonuses (HP, AP, Soak, Movement, Skills), lineage trait registration, trauma baseline, background skill grants, derived stat calculation and application, resource pool initialization (Stamina, Aether Pool at maximum), archetype starting abilities (3), specialization application (Tier 1 abilities, special resource), and saga progression initialization (PP: 0, Rank: 1). Coordinates with ILineageProvider, IBackgroundProvider, IArchetypeProvider, ISpecializationProvider, and IDerivedStatCalculator.
terms.shortDefinition: Service creating fully initialized Player entities from completed creation state.

terms.definition: Immutable value object (readonly record struct) representing the outcome of validating a CharacterCreationState before character creation. Contains IsValid (bool) indicating whether all required selections are present and consistent, and Errors (IReadOnlyList<string>) listing user-friendly validation failure descriptions. Checks include: all selections present (lineage, background, attributes, archetype, specialization, name), attribute allocation complete (IsComplete), Clan-Born flexible bonus selected, and specialization-archetype compatibility. Created via factory methods Valid() and Invalid(params string[]).
terms.shortDefinition: Validation result for character creation state completeness and consistency.

terms.definition: Contract (ICreationScreen) for character creation step screens. Defines a Step property (CharacterCreationStep) and a DisplayAsync method that renders the screen using Spectre.Console's IAnsiConsole and returns a ScreenResult containing the user's action (Continue, GoBack, Cancel) and optional selection data. Implemented by LineageScreen, BackgroundScreen, AttributeScreen, ArchetypeScreen, SpecializationScreen, and SummaryScreen.
terms.shortDefinition: Interface contract for character creation step screen implementations.

terms.definition: Top-level orchestrator view (CreationWizardView) that drives the six-step character creation workflow. Coordinates between ICharacterCreationController (state and validation) and ICreationScreen implementations (rendering and interaction). Routes the workflow loop: Initialize → get state → find screen → display → process result. Handles navigation (GoBack calls controller.GoBack(), Cancel calls controller.Cancel()), submits selections to the controller, and returns the created Player entity on completion or null on cancellation.
terms.shortDefinition: Orchestrator view driving the six-step character creation wizard loop.

terms.definition: Static shared component (StepHeaderRenderer) that renders the step header section for character creation screens using Spectre.Console. Displays step number and title as a Rule, step description as markup text, and a yellow warning Panel for permanent choices (e.g., Archetype selection). Also provides RenderProgress() for showing filled/empty step indicators based on current progress through the wizard.
terms.shortDefinition: Shared component for rendering step headers and progress in creation screens.

terms.definition: Static shared component (OptionListRenderer) that builds Spectre.Console SelectionPrompt instances with consistent styling for character creation screens. Provides navigation constants (BackChoice: '< Back', CancelChoice: 'Cancel Creation'), prompt creation with optional back navigation, TryParseNavigation() for mapping navigation choices to ScreenResult, and RenderValidationErrors() for displaying error lists.
terms.shortDefinition: Shared component for building selection prompts with navigation in creation screens.

terms.definition: Immutable value object (readonly record struct) representing the outcome of displaying a character creation screen. Contains Action (ScreenAction enum: Continue, GoBack, Cancel) and Selection (object? — the user's choice, type varies by step). Created via factory methods: Selected(object) for Continue with data, GoBack() for back navigation, Cancel() for workflow cancellation. Consumed by CreationWizardView to route the wizard loop.
terms.shortDefinition: Value object representing the outcome of a creation screen display.

terms.definition: Enum (ScreenAction) defining the three possible navigation outcomes from a character creation screen: Continue (0) — user made a selection and wants to proceed, GoBack (1) — user wants to return to the previous step, Cancel (2) — user wants to abort the entire creation workflow. Used as the Action property of ScreenResult and consumed by CreationWizardView's main loop switch statement.
terms.shortDefinition: Enum for creation screen navigation actions: Continue, GoBack, Cancel.

terms.definition: Interface (IPlayerRepository) defining the persistence contract for Player entities created through the character creation workflow. Provides methods for saving newly created characters, retrieving by ID or most recent, checking name uniqueness (case-insensitive), updating existing characters, and listing all saved characters. Currently implemented by InMemoryPlayerRepository; future EF Core implementation planned.
terms.shortDefinition: Repository interface for Player entity persistence operations.

terms.definition: Value object (SaveResult) representing the outcome of a persistence operation on an entity. Contains either a successful outcome with the saved entity's Guid ID or a failure with a descriptive error message. Created via factory methods: SaveResult.Succeeded(Guid) and SaveResult.Failed(string). Used by IPlayerRepository to communicate save/update outcomes to the CharacterCreationController.
terms.shortDefinition: Value object for persistence operation outcomes (success with ID or failure with error).

terms.definition: Thread-safe in-memory implementation of IPlayerRepository using ConcurrentDictionary. Stores Player entities keyed by ID with separate timestamp tracking for ordering. Enforces case-insensitive name uniqueness. Data is lost when the application stops. Suitable for development, testing, and scenarios where database persistence is not yet configured. Registered as a singleton in DI.
terms.shortDefinition: Thread-safe in-memory implementation of player persistence.
